comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
That yoke looks more like an "Autocycle" as distinct from a motor cycle Carol.  There used to be a distinction between the two, a motorcycle was built to be motorised but an Autocycle was a bike with engine, usually a small 2 stroke mounted on the front wheel but occasionally driving the chain as in this one.
But I could be all wrong - again;-)))

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Donegal News of Saturday, 17 September 1904...
SOME QUEER CASES AT MALIN PETTY SESSIONS At the last Malin petty sessions ... Sergeant James Gillespie, of Malin Head, charged [long list of defendants, who did not appear], all of Ardmalin, with being on the licensed premises of Mrs. Margaret O'Doherty during prohibited hours. ... Sergeant Gillespie stated that on Sunday, the 17th July, at about twelve o'clock noon he was returning from Divine service and noticed several persons enter the back yard of the licensed premises. He went into the yard after them, and asked them to account for their presence. Some of the defendants walked away without replying, but other stated they were there in connection with salmon fishing. On inquiring from Mr. Patrick O'Doherty he found that statement to be false. ... [legal to-ing and fro-ing] Mr. Scott [presiding]: Is it not a usual practice for persons of that locality to stop about the yard of Mrs. O'Doherty's premises on a Sunday - I won't say for the purpose of getting drink, but simply hanging around? Sergeant Gillespie: I do not think so. If I saw them I would certainly prosecute. Mr. Scott: Well, I have seen it myself. ... Colonel Tynte, R.M.: Are you going to oppose the granting of a certificate to the publican, this being the sessions for the granting of certificates? Sergeant Gillespie: No. It was ultimately announced by the Chairman that the bench decided to impose a penalty of 1s. on each of the defendants. Colonel Tynte, R.M.: If the publican does not put gates on the yard you can oppose the licence next sessions. Mr. Marks, D.I.: Very well, your worship.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Just had a quick look for Magnus on Ancestry and can find absolutely nothing. Odd. Would be good to get a make and date on that bike. Can you make out anything on the fuel tank?

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: So, does anyone have any ideas on location? There are really only a few hotels/pubs in Malin - so the candidate pool is small. The Seaview Tavern looks like a possible (if unconvincing) candidate. (OSI | GMaps). Certainly the current owner is a Doherty. (But then everyone in the area was/is called Doherty (or Quigley or Farren) so using name alone makes things difficult...)

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] I was wondering, if Sergeant Gillespie was returning from Divine service, presumably to his home at Malin Head, can we work out start and end points and hence route?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Not the Seaview Tavern, I think, as it was named that way on the OS 25" in 1900. The only bar north of the Seaview today is Farren's bar in Slievebane, and I don't think that's it, either, with the hayfields visible over the wall here.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] great work

comment.author: 13073434@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I knew of the term 'auto cycle'. That would fit in with my perception of the name. It has an engine and pedals. It is also belt driven as opposed to chain driven. On another note - the porch is a new addition judging by the new render (different coloured) above its roof.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Not a million miles away:

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Agreed. I don't think it's Farren's either. However, if it's not Seaview, then I wonder whether something is amiss. I say this because the House and Building Returns for 1901 and 1911 only show 2 public houses in the entire district: Doherty's (an "18 window-er" which stacks up with the photo), and Farren's (a "5 window-er" which doesn't). Everything else is a private dwelling (apart from the Coast Guard building and RIC Barracks). So, if Seaview is not Margaret Doherty's pub, then Seaview is "missing" from the return. (Or categorised as a grocers - which is plausible - but not really likely.)

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: I would say custom made!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Constabulary Barracks was just a stones throw behind the Seaview, making Sergeant Gillespie's story plausible...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: But the Seaview did not have a walled yard in front in 1900, and I can't get that view behind the wall to line up...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: It's now the "Crossroads Inn" at Ballygorman. Streetview You can just about make out the road surface behind the bush and beyond the far gate 25" OSI ( June 1900) The porch above was built after the survey of June 1900 The plaster looks very fresh.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Perfect! Also on Sergeant Gillespie's route from more or less anywhere to the Barracks.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I don't know if there still is, but there was a shop in the bar.  I had a part time job as a youngster delivering bread (20 years ago, but I'm still young!), and The Crossroads was on the route.  There was a step just inside the door, and walking in with an armful of bread you had to watch your step.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] James Gillespie, like fellow RIC men at the time didn't state his occupation or religion on the census return. But one look at the rest of his family and it's pretty obvious he kicked with the right foot. The RC church is just down the road from the public house where he was coming from his Divine service. www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Donegal/Ardmali...

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: Looking at Streetview, the stained glass in the extension remains!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] Well spotted.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: It's definitely a Triumph 3.5HP motorbicycle and it seems only the 1907 model had both the advance/retard and mixture levers on the LH side of the tank. The paint work around the crest on the tank is also different on earlier and later models.

comment.author: 24469639@N00
comment._content: Loving the way that this has all come together. Great work all round.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So, the bike says 1907 or later, and before 1911 when Mr. Krenty of London owned it?

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Yes, post 1907 but maybe there's the possibility Krenty,while having an his home address in London,may have been working in the Marconi station and so was still in Donegal post 1911.  There is a car reg # HI 61 in the directory owned by the Marconi Co.with their address in London. It seems one didn't have to live in the county to register a car in that county.
